items.dek: If it's summer outside, it should be summer on your plate. So let other people relegate summer cooking to weekend picnics and road trips. You? You're going to bring summer to the table all day, every day.

items.section1Dek: Stop, um, dogging on hot dogs. With the proper technique (and some amazing toppings), they can be just as juicy, sophisticated, and fabulous as steaks and burgers.
items.section2Dek: It's hot. You're hungry. So let us make this easy: Here are two strategies that offer minimum effort, maximum reward.
items.dek: If it's summer outside, it should be summer on your plate. So let other people relegate summer cooking to weekend picnics and road trips. You? You're going to bring summer to the table every day, all day.
items.seoTitle: The Easiest Recipes to Cook This Summer
items.seoDescription: From hot dogs and slow cooker sandwiches to pies and cocktails, all the recipes you need are here.
items.socialTitle: How to Have the Most Delicious (and Easiest) Summer Ever
items.socialDescription: Summer eating isn't just about cookouts, picnics, and road trips. Here's how to make the average Thursday taste like vacation.
items.section5Dek: Never made pie on a Tuesday? You will now.

fields.title: Summer 100: Summer Every Day Package Illo

items.dek: What do you call the time of year when the greens are tender, the tomatoes are sweet, and the cucumbers are crunchy? Oh yeah: salad days. Grab a big bowl—we're going to make the most of them.
items.seoTitle: Sensational Salad Recipes, Advice, and Techniques
items.seoDescription: Salad recipes, techniques, dressings, and tips.
items.socialTitle: Everything You Need to Make Sensational Salads
items.socialDescription: Recipes, techniques, dressings, and the surprise ingredient you're probably leaving out.

fields.promoTitle: Herb Salad with Pistachios, Fennel, and Horseradish
fields.title: Herb Salad with Pistachios, Fennel, and Horseradish

items.seoDescription: Our best burgers for Memorial Day Weekend
items.socialDescription: Here are the burgers you'll go HAM for.

items.caption: Crisp on the outside, juicy on the inside. It's not a myth, and here's why: Freezing the patties for 15 minutes before cooking prevents them from cooking too quickly in the middle, which gives you time to get that deeply browned crust.
This burger packs on smoky flavor three ways: chipotle chiles mingled with adobo, smoked paprika, and bacon. Throw on a sliced seared avocado, because it's just always a good idea.
items.credit: Photo by Jeffery Schad and Chris Gentile

items.caption: For good burgers, it's the inside that counts. Selecting your own cuts and grinding the meat yourself guarantees the perfect meat ratios.
This burger blows smoke and heat at your hamburger expectations. Topped with peppery watercress, a spiced ketchup, and flavored with miso.
Every bite counts on a burger. This gooey Wisconsin cheddar-topped burger leaves you wanting one more bite of cabernet-cooked onion.

Butter+burger=no brainer. Put a pat of tangy meyer lemon butter into the center of each beef patty. As the burger cooks, the butter melts, giving the meat an extra-tender texture and a hit of citrusy flavor.
How to make a healthier burger? Look to where the buffalo roam. Buffalo meat is lower in fat than beef, and with a tart celery root and apple slaw, it taste better, too.
The burger has worcestershire written all over it. Using the umami-rich sauce with sugar and coffee makes a sweet and savory glaze that's your secret to a better burger.
This rich red pepper buttermilk sauce>ketchup.
Burgers love heat but we hate flare-ups. What's a burger meister to do? Cook these sweet caramelized onion and bacon burgers on indirect heat. Flip only once and relax while you wait.

fields.caption: Classic Smashed Cheeseburger
fields.credit: Charles Masters, food styling by Chelsea Zimmer
fields.title: Classic Smashed Cheeseburger

items.hed: 5 Reasons to Take Tequila Beyond Margaritas
items.dek: Margaritas are great, but there's whole world of tequila cocktails out there.
items.promoHed: 5 Reasons to Take Tequila Beyond Margaritas
items.seoDescription: Here are margarita alternatives for this Cinco de Mayo
items.socialTitle: 5 Reasons to Put Down the Margarita This Cinco de Mayo
items.socialDescription: Here are margarita alternatives for this Cinco de Mayo
items.body:
While we love a well-made margarita, sometimes it's nice to shake things up. Here are five tequila-ready cocktails that turn up the heat and give the margarita some competition.

####Paloma####
The Paloma deserves to be more than second fiddle. The stirred combination of tequila, lime juice, and grapefruit soda is just as refreshing as a margarita. Skip the overly sweet and syrupy supermarket sodas by making your own base of grapefruit juice, simple syrup, and club soda. And to give your cocktail some smoke in no time, try [grilling your citrus](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/grilled-paloma-51237030) or [substituting tequila for mezcal](http://www.epicurious.com/ingredients/it-s-time-to-start-drinking-mezcal-the-booze-that-will-make-your-cocktails-smoky-article).

[#recipe: /recipes/54a426ad19925f464b37bd01]||||||

####Michelada####
Micheladas are the Mexican cocktail that don't feel like a cocktail. Take one beer—we're partial to an inexpensive Mexican lager—pour in spiced sauce, lime juice, and salt. Stir. Drink. Have another. Try mixing in some [Worcestershire sauce](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/michelada-239743) and [tomato juice](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/michelada-51160860) for extra savory notes. This version below includes the smoky punch of mezcal:

[#recipe: /recipes/54a41f3519925f464b377443]||||||

####A Bloody "Maria"####
Ah, the eye-opening brunch cocktail, made even hairier by [substituting tequila for vodka](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/tequila-bloody-mary-200706). Try using canned chipotles in adobo to add some [smoky dimension](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/southwestern-bloody-mary-201161) (and a lot of extra heat you can’t always find in bottled hot sauces).  

[#recipe: /recipes/54a43cf019925f464b38a2e2]||||||

####El Diablo####
Fans of [Kir Royales](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/kir-royale-102788) will love this. This riff on a traditional Diablo is a blend of ginger beer, tequila, and crème de cassis. Sometimes made with pomegranate instead of black currant syrup, this sweet and floral cocktail is easy sipping for a Cinco de Mayo celebration.

[#recipe: /recipes/54a42ca019925f464b380698]||||||


####Tequila Sunrise####
Time to bring a new day to the oft-despised tequila sunrise. This [layered drink](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/tequila-sunrise-200692) uses tequila, orange juice, and grenadine—kind of like an orange margarita. The name comes from the separation of syrup and orange juice, [best seen in a highball glass](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/tequila-sunrise-ii-200744). The drink’s bad reputation comes from the poor quality of syrup, and from the bad decisions a hefty pour of tequila can inspire. The store-bought versions of grenadine are saturated with artificial flavoring and coloring—[make your own](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/homemade-grenadine-236104) or buy [a high quality version](http://jackrudycocktailco.com/purchase/mixers/small-batch-grenadine/). And if you really can’t shake the craving for a blender drink, make a [frozen-over tequila sunrise](http://www.epicurious.com/recipes/food/views/frozen-sunrise-margaritas-51147200).

[#recipe: /recipes/54a436836529d92b2c018b13]||||||


[#gallery: /galleries/55256df5b329bd276d93d142]||||||
